content.question: Which statement about the power of a significance test is true?

choices.label: A test performed at a significance level of <math alttext="alpha equals 0.01" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.01</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> has a higher power than the same test performed at a significance level of <math alttext="alpha equals 0.05" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
If the probability of Type <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> error is decreased, the power of the test is increased.
The power of a test is equal to the probability of making a Type <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> error.
The power of a test is independent of the sample size.
The power of a test at a particular parameter value increases as the distance from the hypothesized value to the parameter value increases.

content.answer: The power of a test at a particular parameter value increases as the distance from the hypothesized value to the parameter value increases.
